net.sf.mmm.client.ui.base.widget

Class AbstractUiWidgetNative<ADAPTER extends UiWidgetAdapter,VALUE>

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.sf.mmm.client.ui.base.feature.AbstractUiFeatureValueAndValidation<VALUE>
      • net.sf.mmm.client.ui.base.widget.AbstractUiWidget<VALUE>
        • net.sf.mmm.client.ui.base.widget.AbstractUiWidgetNative<ADAPTER,VALUE>
  • Type Parameters:
    ADAPTER - is the generic type of getWidgetAdapter().
    VALUE - is the generic type of the value. Use Void for no value.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    AttributeReadAriaRole, AttributeReadEnabled, AttributeReadHtmlId, AttributeReadMode, AttributeReadModeFixed, AttributeReadModified, AttributeReadPrimaryStyle, AttributeReadStyles, AttributeReadStylesAdvanced, AttributeReadTooltip, AttributeReadValueAdvanced<VALUE>, AttributeReadVisible, AttributeReadVisibleRecursive, AttributeWriteAriaRole, AttributeWriteEnabled, AttributeWriteHtmlId, AttributeWriteMode, AttributeWriteModeFixed, AttributeWriteModified, AttributeWriteOnlyFocused, AttributeWritePrimaryStyle, AttributeWriteStyles, AttributeWriteStylesAdvanced, AttributeWriteTooltip, AttributeWriteValueAdvanced<VALUE>, AttributeWriteVisible, AttributeWriteVisibleAdvanced, UiFeature, UiFeatureEvent, UiFeatureMessages, UiFeatureMode, UiFeatureValidation<VALUE>, UiFeatureValue<VALUE>, UiFeatureValueAndValidation<VALUE>, UiWidget, UiWidgetAbstractComposite, UiWidgetAbstractWithValue<VALUE>, AttributeReadDisposed, AttributeReadId<String>, AttributeReadValue<VALUE>, AttributeWriteDisposed, AttributeWriteId<String>, AttributeWriteValue<VALUE>, Accessibility, AbstractValidatableObject, HasValueValidators<VALUE>, ValidatableObject<VALUE>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    AbstractUiWidgetActive, AbstractUiWidgetComposite, AbstractUiWidgetMenuItemSeparator, AbstractUiWidgetRegularAtomic, AbstractUiWidgetTableColumn, AbstractUiWidgetWithLabel

    public abstract class AbstractUiWidgetNative<ADAPTER extends UiWidgetAdapter,VALUE>
extends AbstractUiWidget<VALUE>
implements UiWidgetAbstractComposite, AttributeWriteAriaRole
    This is the abstract base implementation of UiWidget or more precisely UiWidgetNative. It is independent of any native toolkit via UiWidgetAdapter that is lazily created.
    If you want to create an implementation of all the UiWidgets for a native UI toolkit, you are strongly encouraged to extend from this class and its subclasses (all classes named AbstractUiWidget*).
    Since:
    1.0.0
    Author:
    Joerg Hohwiller (hohwille at users.sourceforge.net)

      • hasWidgetAdapter

        public final boolean hasWidgetAdapter()
        Specified by:
        hasWidgetAdapter in class AbstractUiWidget<VALUE>
        Returns:
        true if the UiWidgetAdapter has already been created. Otherwise false (if AbstractUiWidget.getWidgetAdapter() has never been called yet).

      • getWidgetAdapter

        protected final ADAPTER getWidgetAdapter()
        This method gets or creates the UiWidgetAdapter.
        ATTENTION:
        On the first call of this method, the UiWidgetAdapter is created. For the purpose of lazy instantiation this should happen as late as possible. Use AbstractUiWidget.hasWidgetAdapter() to prevent unnecessary creation.
        Specified by:
        getWidgetAdapter in class AbstractUiWidget<VALUE>
        Returns:
        the UiWidgetAdapter.

      • getWidgetAdapter

        public static final <A extends UiWidgetAdapter> A getWidgetAdapter(AbstractUiWidgetNative<A,?> widget)
        This method gives access to getWidgetAdapter().
        ATTENTION:
        This method is only for internal purposes when implementing UiWidgets. It shall never be used by regular users (what also applies for all classes in this base packages).
        Type Parameters:
        A - is the generic type of getWidgetAdapter().
        Parameters:
        widget - is the widget.
        Returns:
        the widget adapter of the given widget.

      • getId

        public String getId()
        This method gets the unique identifier of this object.
        ATTENTION:
        In order to be compliant with all possible UI toolkit implementations, a valid ID has to fulfill ECMA-262, Section 7.6. It is recommended to use IDs of the form [a-zA-Z][a-zA-Z0-9_$]*. Invalid IDs (e.g. containing colon, hash or period) are not accepted to prevent you from later having problems with CSS selectors.
        Specified by:
        getId in interface AttributeReadHtmlId
        Specified by:
        getId in interface AttributeReadId<String>
        Returns:
        the ID of this object.
        See Also:
        AttributeReadHtmlId.ID_SEPARATOR

      • setFocused

        public boolean setFocused()
        This method sets the focus to this object.
        NOTE:
        You can only set the focus. To actually remove it, you need to set it in a different widget. Further, as an API user you can normally ignore the result. This is only relevant for composite widgets such as panels, that delegate the call recursively and may not contain any child that can take the focus.
        Specified by:
        setFocused in interface AttributeWriteOnlyFocused
        Returns:
        true if the focus has been set successfully, false otherwise.

      • setMode

        public final void setMode(UiMode mode)
        This method sets the mode of this object. It will change the object to view or edit mode. This is a recursive operation that will also apply to all descendants of this object. If a fixed mode is set (not null), this method will have no effect and recursive calls will stop at this object.

      • getModeFixed

        public UiMode getModeFixed()
        This method gets the fixed UiMode of this object. While a fixed UiMode is set (NOT null) changing the mode will have no effect.
        Specified by:
        getModeFixed in interface AttributeReadModeFixed
        Returns:
        the fixed UiMode or null if the UiMode may be changed.

      • setModeFixed

        public void setModeFixed(UiMode modeFixed)
        This method sets the fixed mode of this object. This will set the mode to the given mode (if not null, recursively) and then mark the mode as fixed so AttributeWriteMode.setMode(UiMode) will have no effect anymore. The fixed mode itself will NOT be set recursively.
        The typical use-case is to set the fixed mode to UiMode.VIEW in order to prevent a UI widget (a field or even an entire sub-dialog) from switching to edit-mode (UiMode.EDIT) so the UI widget will always remain read-only.
        Specified by:
        setModeFixed in interface AttributeWriteModeFixed
        Parameters:
        modeFixed - is the new fixed UiMode to set. May be null to unset fixation.

      • isVisible

        public boolean isVisible()
        This method determines if this object is set to visible.
        ATTENTION:
        This method is an efficient shortcut for AttributeWriteVisibleAdvanced.getVisibleFlag().getFlag(). If you want to read the value that has been set via AttributeWriteVisibleAdvanced.setVisible(boolean) you would need to do AttributeWriteVisibleAdvanced.getVisibleFlag().getFlag(null) instead. See AttributeWriteVisibleAdvanced.getVisibleFlag() for more information.
        Specified by:
        isVisible in interface AttributeReadVisible
        Specified by:
        isVisible in interface AttributeWriteVisibleAdvanced
        Returns:
        true if programmatically set visible, false if directly programmatically hidden.
        See Also:
        AttributeReadVisibleRecursive.isVisibleRecursive()

      • getVisibleFlag

        public AttributeWriteFlagAdvanced getVisibleFlag()
        This method gets advanced visibility support. It allows you to read and write the visibility for different cross-cutting concerns.
        Motivation:
        Typical UI toolkits provide visibility as a primitive boolean attribute or property. However, this is leading to various problems if you have multiple aspects that influence the flag. E.g. assume you have some dynamic effect that is showing or hiding a widget. Additionally the widget is in a collapsable section, tab-panel, or the like that is also showing or hiding the widget. Further, there might be an authorization in your application as a cross-cutting concern that hides widgets from the UI according to the current roles and permissions of the user. If this is all based on a simple boolean flag you will end up in a mess and with a buggy application. So the dynamic effect or even worse the authorization will hide the widget but after the user collapses and then expands a panel it becomes visible again. You do not want to deal with bugs like this.
        ATTENTION:
        The returned instance may be lazily created. It will not be expensive but for a large UI this will sum up. In a web or especially a mobile client memory might be low. So if you are recursively traversing the UI widget tree you should only rely on AttributeWriteVisibleAdvanced.isVisible() for reading visibility.
        Specified by:
        getVisibleFlag in interface AttributeWriteVisibleAdvanced
        Returns:
        the mutable flag for advanced visibility support.

      • isVisibleRecursive

        public final boolean isVisibleRecursive()
        This method determines if this object is actually visible for the end-user. In advance to AttributeReadVisible.isVisible() it also takes its parent objects into account. So it only returns true if the object is actually attached to the UI and physically in the current dialogue (it may still be clipped from the screen or scrolled out of the visible panel).
        Specified by:
        isVisibleRecursive in interface AttributeReadVisibleRecursive
        Returns:
        true if visible to the end-user, false otherwise.

      • getTooltip

        public String getTooltip()
        This method gets the tooltip of this object. It is a brief description that explains this object. If the user remains on the object (e.g. with the mouse pointer) this tooltip is displayed as hover.
        Specified by:
        getTooltip in interface AttributeReadTooltip

      • getAriaRole

        public Role getAriaRole()
        This method gets the Accessibility.WAI_ARIA role of this object.
        ATTENTION:
        A reasonable UI framework (e.g. when using UiWidget) is supposed to provide high-level widgets and support setting the according Role and their attributes automatically. Therefore users should only use this for special situations e.g. for setting aria-hidden intentionally for a visible object.
        Specified by:
        getAriaRole in interface AttributeReadAriaRole
        Returns:
        the Role or null if NOT set.
        See Also:
        Accessibility

      • getAriaRoleFixedType

        protected Class<? extends Role> getAriaRoleFixedType()
        Returns:
        the Class reflecting the Role that is fixed for this widget or null if the role can be changed dynamically.

      • setAriaRole

        public <ROLE extends Role> ROLE setAriaRole(Class<ROLE> roleType)
        This method sets the ARIA role of this object.
        NOTE:
        If you are using the UI-Toolkit (UiWidget) the roles are automatically set for according widgets. There is no need to e.g. manually set RoleCombobox to a UiWidgetComboBox. Therefore, you only need to set roles explicitly for specific custom features. ATTENTION:
        This method will fail if an abstract Role is given.
        Specified by:
        setAriaRole in interface AttributeWriteAriaRole
        Type Parameters:
        ROLE - is the generic type of the new Role.
        Parameters:
        roleType - is the interface of the new ARIA role. Must not be an abstract Role interface.
        Returns:
        the instance of the new Role that is connected to this object.
        See Also:
        AttributeReadAriaRole.getAriaRole(), Accessibility

      • getStyles

        public String getStyles()
        This method gets the style(s) (also called style-name(s)) of this object. The style defines aspects for the appearance (look & feel) of a UI element when displayed to the user.
        If you are familiar with web-technology just think of this as the class attribute of HTML elements that are then configured via some cascading style sheet (CSS).
        The following situations can be distinguished:
        • no style
          The empty string is returned.
        • single style
          The name of that single style is returned. The result does NOT contain any whitespace.
        • multiple styles
          The list of individual styles are separated by whitespaces in the result.
        Each individual style has to match AttributeReadStyles.STYLE_PATTERN_SINGLE. Any number of styles or in other words the result of this has to match AttributeReadStyles.STYLE_PATTERN_MULTIPLE. The first style is called the primary style.
        Specified by:
        getStyles in interface AttributeReadStyles
        Returns:
        the style(s) of this object.

      • setStyles

        public void setStyles(String styles)
        This method clears all styles and sets them to the given styles. This will also update the primary style.
        Specified by:
        setStyles in interface AttributeWriteStyles
        Parameters:
        styles - are the styles of this object. Either a single style or a list of styles separated by whitespaces. Use the empty string to unset all styles.

      • getPrimaryStyle

        public String getPrimaryStyle()
        This method gets the primary style of this object.
        Specified by:
        getPrimaryStyle in interface AttributeReadPrimaryStyle
        Returns:
        the primary style of this object. Will be null if NOT defined.

      • doValidate

        protected void doValidate(ValidationState state,
                          VALUE value)
        This method is called from AbstractUiFeatureValueAndValidation.validate(ValidationState) and performs the actual validation of this object. This method performs the recursive validation of potential children of this widget excluding the validation of this widget itself. A legal implementation of a composite widget needs to call AbstractUiFeatureValueAndValidation.validate(ValidationState) on all child widgets.
        It performs the validation of this widget by delegating to validateRecursive(ValidationState). It may be overridden to collect potential validation failures and attach them to this widget. You should not forget the super-call in such case.
        Overrides:
        doValidate in class AbstractUiWidget<VALUE>
        Parameters:
        state - is the ValidationState. Never null.
        value - is the current value of this object that has already be determined.

      • validateRecursive

        void validateRecursive(ValidationState state)
        This method performs the recursive validation of potential children of this widget excluding the validation of this widget itself. A legal implementation of a composite widget needs to call AbstractUiFeatureValueAndValidation.validate(ValidationState) on all child widgets.
        Parameters:
        state - is the ValidationState.

      • doSetValue

        protected void doSetValue(VALUE value,
                          boolean forUser)
        This method is called from the data-binding triggered by API methods such as AbstractUiWidget.setValue(Object, boolean). In many cases the data-binding already performs the required work to do. However, here is the place to implemented the custom logic to get the value from the actual widget. For details see AbstractUiWidget.doGetValue(Object, ValidationState).
        Overrides:
        doSetValue in class AbstractUiWidget<VALUE>
        Parameters:
        value - is the value to set. Typically a composite object (e.g. java bean) so its attributes are set to fields (see UiWidgetField).
        forUser - true if called from AbstractUiFeatureValueAndValidation.setValueForUser(Object), false if set from AbstractUiFeatureValueAndValidation.setValue(Object).
        See Also:
        AbstractUiWidget.doGetValue(Object, ValidationState)

      • doGetValue

        protected VALUE doGetValue(VALUE template,
                           ValidationState state)
                    throws RuntimeException
        This method is called from the data-binding triggered by API methods such as AbstractUiFeatureValueAndValidation.getValue(). In many cases the data-binding already performs the required work to do. However, here is the place to implemented the custom logic to get the value from the actual widget. The following cases have to be distinguished:
        • For native fields this method has to get the actual value from the underlying native widget (text-box, password-field, etc.).
        • For custom fields this method will be responsible to convert from the delegates value (see UiWidgetCustom.getDelegate()) to the proper value type. E.g. if you want to create a custom widget to edit your own datatype such as CustomerNumber based on a UiWidgetTextField you need to convert from String to CustomerNumber.
        • For custom composite widgets you should use AbstractUiWidget.getDataBinding(). UiDataBinding.createAndBind(net.sf.mmm.util.pojo.path.api.TypedProperty) that gives you high-level support and makes your live easy. Then there is no need to override this method.
        • For other cases, especially if <VALUE> is Void, there is nothing to do here.
        The implementation of this method has to correspond with the implementation of AbstractUiWidget.doSetValue(Object, boolean) .
        Overrides:
        doGetValue in class AbstractUiWidget<VALUE>
        Parameters:
        template - is the object where the data is filled in. May only be null if according to data-binding (e.g. if <VALUE> is an (immutable) Datatype).
        state - is the ValidationState. May be null (if the validation is omitted). Should only be used to propagate to AbstractUiWidget.getValueDirect(Object, ValidationState) of children.
        Returns:
        the current value of this widget. May be null if empty. If <VALUE> is String the empty String has to be returned if no value has been entered. In case <VALUE> is a mutable object (java bean) the template is NOT null and is to be returned by this method after the value(s) of this widget have been assigned. For immutable datatypes template will be null and this method has to create a new instance of <VALUE> based on the end-users input in the widget.
        Throws:
        RuntimeException
        See Also:
        AbstractUiWidget.doSetValue(Object, boolean)
